Module com.gluonhq.richtextarea
Package com.gluonhq.richtextarea

Class RichTextArea

java.lang.Object
javafx.scene.Node
javafx.scene.Parent
javafx.scene.layout.Region
javafx.scene.control.Control
com.gluonhq.richtextarea.RichTextArea
All Implemented Interfaces:
javafx.css.Styleable, javafx.event.EventTarget, javafx.scene.control.Skinnable
public class RichTextArea extends javafx.scene.control.Control
The RichTextArea control is a text input component that allows a user to enter multiple lines of rich text and other non-text objects like images or hyperlinks. Internally the data model is based on a PieceTable implementation. Pieces hold text and decorations that can be applied to style the text (like font or color) and the paragraph with such text (like paragraph alignment). Unlimited undo/redo operations are allowed. A DecorationModel is used to represent text and paragraph decorations for a given segment of content. A list of DecorationModel and the full text forms the Document, which is the model that ultimately the control renders.

    Methods inherited from interface javafx.css.Styleable

    getStyleableNode

  • Property Details

    • document

      public final javafx.beans.property.ObjectProperty<Document> documentProperty
      The document is the model that holds the full text and decorations that are being displayed by the control. By default, this property is set via ActionFactory.newDocument() or ActionFactory.open(Document), and gets updated only via ActionFactory.save(), unless autoSaveProperty() is enabled, in which the document gets updated after every change.
      See Also:
      • getDocument()
      • setDocument(Document)
      • documentProperty()

    • autoSave

      public final javafx.beans.property.BooleanProperty autoSaveProperty
      Property that allows saving every change done into the document. By default, it is disabled, and it is recommended to use the ActionFactory.save() action instead, on user's demand: If auto save is enabled, there might be some impact on performance.
      See Also:
      • isAutoSave()
      • setAutoSave(boolean)
      • autoSaveProperty()

    • modified

      public final javafx.beans.property.ReadOnlyBooleanProperty modifiedProperty
      Indicates if the current document has unsaved changes or not. Unless autoSaveProperty() is enabled, after any change of the document being edited with the control this property will be set to true, and will enable the ActionFactory.save() action.
      See Also:
      • isModified()
      • modifiedProperty()

    • editable

      public final javafx.beans.property.BooleanProperty editableProperty
      Indicates if the document is editable or not. By default, it is set to true.
      See Also:
      • isEditable()
      • setEditable(boolean)
      • editableProperty()

    • selection

      public final javafx.beans.property.ReadOnlyObjectProperty<Selection> selectionProperty
      Contains the selection of some fragment of the document, if any.
      See Also:
      • getSelection()
      • selectionProperty()

    • textLength

      public final javafx.beans.property.ReadOnlyIntegerProperty textLengthProperty
      Returns the current length of the document, and it gets updated after every change, even if the document has not been saved yet.
      See Also:
      • getTextLength()
      • textLengthProperty()

    • contentAreaWidth

      public final javafx.beans.property.DoubleProperty contentAreaWidthProperty
      Defines a width constraint for the content area of the rich text control, in user space coordinates, where text can be added. The width is measured in pixels (and not glyph or character count). If the value is <= 0, the content area extends to the whole viewport of control and will change whenever the viewport gets resized. If the value is > 0, the content area is exactly set to this value, and the control will provide a horizontal scrollbar if needed. In any case, text will be line wrapped as needed to satisfy this constraint.
      Default value:
      0
      See Also:
      • getContentAreaWidth()
      • setContentAreaWidth(double)
      • contentAreaWidthProperty()

    • paragraphGraphicFactory

      public final javafx.beans.property.ObjectProperty<BiFunction<Integer,ParagraphDecoration.GraphicType,javafx.scene.Node>> paragraphGraphicFactoryProperty
      A paragraph can be decorated with a node to the left. This property allows adding the graphic for numbered or bulleted lists. Once the indentation level and the graphic type for a given paragraph are set, for instance with the ParagraphDecorateAction, the BiFunction allows defining the node that will be used for the graphic with such indentation level and type of list. Numbered lists should use a Label as node. The text of the label should contain, at least, an "#" as a wildcard for the index of paragraph, which will be automatically determined by the control. By default, the control provides a factory.
      See Also:
      • getParagraphGraphicFactory()
      • setParagraphGraphicFactory(BiFunction)
      • paragraphGraphicFactoryProperty()

    • linkCallbackFactory

      public final javafx.beans.property.ObjectProperty<Function<javafx.scene.Node,Consumer<String>>> linkCallbackFactoryProperty
      Allows setting a consumer that accepts a valid URL string, for a given node. Typically, this can be applied to Text or ImageView nodes with a link to a given URL. A default factory allows opening this link in the browser.
      See Also:
      • getLinkCallbackFactory()
      • setLinkCallbackFactory(Function)
      • linkCallbackFactoryProperty()

    • onAction

      public final javafx.beans.property.ObjectProperty<javafx.event.EventHandler<javafx.event.ActionEvent>> onActionProperty
      Defines the action to be performed when enter is pressed. If no action is set, a new line will be added by default.
      See Also:
      • getOnAction()
      • setOnAction(EventHandler)
      • onActionProperty()

    • skinTone

      public final javafx.beans.property.ObjectProperty<com.gluonhq.emoji.EmojiSkinTone> skinToneProperty
      See Also:
      • getSkinTone()
      • setSkinTone(EmojiSkinTone)
      • skinToneProperty()

    • caretPosition

      public final javafx.beans.property.ReadOnlyIntegerProperty caretPositionProperty
      The current position of the caret within the text.
      See Also:
      • getCaretPosition()
      • caretPositionProperty()

    • tableAllowed

      public final javafx.beans.property.BooleanProperty tableAllowedProperty
      See Also:
      • isTableAllowed()
      • setTableAllowed(boolean)
      • tableAllowedProperty()

    • promptText

      public final javafx.beans.property.StringProperty promptTextProperty
      The prompt text to display in the Document. If set to null or an empty string, no prompt text is displayed. Prompt text changes are not handled by the command manager and therefore cannot be undone/redone.
      Default value:
      An empty String
      See Also:
      • getPromptText()
      • setPromptText(String)
      • promptTextProperty()

    • contentAreaWidthProperty

      public final javafx.beans.property.DoubleProperty contentAreaWidthProperty()
      Defines a width constraint for the content area of the rich text control, in user space coordinates, where text can be added. The width is measured in pixels (and not glyph or character count). If the value is <= 0, the content area extends to the whole viewport of control and will change whenever the viewport gets resized. If the value is > 0, the content area is exactly set to this value, and the control will provide a horizontal scrollbar if needed. In any case, text will be line wrapped as needed to satisfy this constraint.
      Default value:
      0
      Returns:
      the width of the content area
      See Also:
      • getContentAreaWidth()
      • setContentAreaWidth(double)

    • getContentAreaWidth

      public final double getContentAreaWidth()
      Gets the value of the contentAreaWidth property.
      Property description:
      Defines a width constraint for the content area of the rich text control, in user space coordinates, where text can be added. The width is measured in pixels (and not glyph or character count). If the value is <= 0, the content area extends to the whole viewport of control and will change whenever the viewport gets resized. If the value is > 0, the content area is exactly set to this value, and the control will provide a horizontal scrollbar if needed. In any case, text will be line wrapped as needed to satisfy this constraint.
      Default value:
      0
      Returns:
      the value of the contentAreaWidth property
      See Also:
      • setContentAreaWidth(double)
      • contentAreaWidthProperty()

    • setContentAreaWidth

      public final void setContentAreaWidth(double value)
      Sets the value of the contentAreaWidth property.
      Property description:
      Defines a width constraint for the content area of the rich text control, in user space coordinates, where text can be added. The width is measured in pixels (and not glyph or character count). If the value is <= 0, the content area extends to the whole viewport of control and will change whenever the viewport gets resized. If the value is > 0, the content area is exactly set to this value, and the control will provide a horizontal scrollbar if needed.       • contentAreaWidthProperty()

    • paragraphGraphicFactoryProperty

      public final javafx.beans.property.ObjectProperty<BiFunction<Integer,ParagraphDecoration.GraphicType,javafx.scene.Node>> paragraphGraphicFactoryProperty()
      A paragraph can be decorated with a node to the left. This property allows adding the graphic for numbered or bulleted lists. Once the indentation level and the graphic type for a given paragraph are set, for instance with the ParagraphDecorateAction, the BiFunction allows defining the node that will be used for the graphic with such indentation level and type of list. Numbered lists should use a Label as node. The text of the label should contain, at least, an "#" as a wildcard for the index of paragraph, which will be automatically determined by the control. By default, the control provides a factory.
      Returns:
      a factory to define the graphic decoration for each paragraph, if any
      See Also:
      • getParagraphGraphicFactory()
      • setParagraphGraphicFactory(BiFunction)

    • getParagraphGraphicFactory

      public final BiFunction<Integer,ParagraphDecoration.GraphicType,javafx.scene.Node> getParagraphGraphicFactory()
      Gets the value of the paragraphGraphicFactory property.
      Property description:
      A paragraph can be decorated with a node to the left. This property allows adding the graphic for numbered or bulleted lists. Once the indentation level and the graphic type for a given paragraph are set, for instance with the ParagraphDecorateAction, the BiFunction allows defining the node that will be used for the graphic with such indentation level and type of list. Numbered lists should use a Label as node. The text of the label should contain, at least, an "#" as a wildcard for the index of paragraph, which will be automatically determined by the control. By default, the control provides a factory.
      Returns:
      the value of the paragraphGraphicFactory property
      See Also:
      • setParagraphGraphicFactory(BiFunction)
      • paragraphGraphicFactoryProperty()

    • linkCallbackFactoryProperty

      public final javafx.beans.property.ObjectProperty<Function<javafx.scene.Node,Consumer<String>>> linkCallbackFactoryProperty()
      Allows setting a consumer that accepts a valid URL string, for a given node. Typically, this can be applied to Text or ImageView nodes with a link to a given URL. A default factory allows opening this link in the browser.
      Returns:
      a factory to process links to URL strings
      See Also:
      • getLinkCallbackFactory()
      • setLinkCallbackFactory(Function)

    • promptTextProperty

      public final javafx.beans.property.StringProperty promptTextProperty()
      The prompt text to display in the Document. If set to null or an empty string, no prompt text is displayed. Prompt text changes are not handled by the command manager and therefore cannot be undone/redone.
      Default value:
      An empty String
      Returns:
      the promptText property
      See Also:
      • getPromptText()
      • setPromptText(String)

    • getPromptText

      public final String getPromptText()

      Property description:

      Default value:
      An empty String
      Returns:
      the value of the promptText property
      See Also:
      • setPromptText(String)
      • promptTextProperty()

    • getActionFactory

      public final ActionFactory getActionFactory()

      Returns:
      the action factory
